ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is exactly what you need to take to learn Chinese. In just this semester, my Chinese abilities have increased immensely. I am amazed by the proficiency in my speaking abilities, writing abilities, and listening comprehension that I have from this class. I feel decently confident enough to lead conversations with native speakers and engage in Chinese material.
I gained speaking, reading, and writing skills!
Developed an introductory proficiency with Chinese.
I improved my Chinese a lot!
Developed and continued to develop the fundamentals of Chinese listening, speaking, reading, writing; really solidified pronunciation, vocabulary, and grammar.
I significantly improved my Chinese and can survive in China now.
This course helped drastically improve my Chinese ability in a short amount of time, especially listening and speaking comprehension, which is hardest

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the Chinese language department at Yale is truly amazing and has designed the course optimally. I think it would be unfair to critique this course as we all have struggled with zoom learning. I look forward to continuing Chinese and in person classes next semester.

I think this course is great and does a good job of immersing the student in the language even though it was all online. A weakness is that some of the questions on homework assignments and exams are really confusing. Sometimes it seems as though questions require us to make huge inferences and can be a little bit misleading at times.
I learned a lot of Chinese and became very well spoken in the language

Strengths: everything about this course is extremely useful for learning, but especially structure -- the Chinese teachers at Yale have it down to a science what they can cover in a semester without overloading you; they create the optimal level of challenge to keep you interested and improving; everything done in class and assigned outside of class is very helpful. Li Laoshi is an amazing teacher. She pushed us, but she is also incredibly kind and she really cares about each of us as students and people.

The only minor weakness for me was character writing -- we do not spend any time writing characters by hand for our assignments, and then we must recall characters on the test. I always managed to remember the majority, but I couldn't remember a significant portion even though I devoted a good amount of study to each character. I wish there were a little more structure to learn characters.
The course is well-organized and highly engaging.

This course is almost all strengths and is run incredibly well. Listening and speaking skills stand out as the most exceptionally gained from this course. Lilaoshi cold calls on us all the time, which can be frightening at first, but it keeps us engaged and really forces us to use the language and always be listening. And whenever we makes mistakes, she finds the perfect way to get us to improve without being mean. The tests for this course are also well-designed. Weaknesses center around the confusion digital layout. The Quia homeworks are randomly spread, and many of the answers do not make sense. Also, we cannot see our grade in real time because the Grades tab is not calculated accurately. This makes for some "in the dark" grading.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought all of the Chinese program's efforts to move their courses online were well thought out and successful. I wish that there had been a different way to assess whether we had learned characters -- if I couldn't remember a character, I didn't write it, but I could easily imagine someone looking up all the characters they didn't remember. I think there could have been a better way to test characters that made it harder to cheat.
The course was well-adapted for the virtual format.

This course felt as if it was in-person, because of the strong engagement. Everyone had microphones on and would talk frequently, and the closeness of the group, combined with the small class, made this possible.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! But only if the student was prepared to do the necessary work to learn Chinese. This is not an easy course and requires daily effort.
Yes!

I would highly recommend this course, and more broadly the Chinese courses at Yale, to any and all students. The material is interesting, challenging, and incredibly rewarding to master, and the course itself is extremely well facilitated with excellent faculty.
Yes it was super helpful in improving my Chinese.

I cannot recommend Chinese at Yale enough -- on an individual level, I know that I have learned a ton, but there's also something special about our Chinese classes in the way that we develop as a group
The course is wonderful, definitely take this course if you want to learn Chinese.

I would strongly recommend this course, if you're serious about learning Chinese. If so, there is no better way to do it than here. But it is a lot of work. Chinese is a demanding language, as is this course. If you just want a little exposure to a foreign language, take something else. But this is top notch.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This course meets everyday to facilitate daily conversational and listening practice. The class is conducted through breakout rooms, Kahoots, reading aloud, and video practice. We also had presentations, writing practice, daily practice, and homework.
One-on-one individual session
Virtual language class
Individual tutorial with TA once a week, individual session with teacher once a week
